titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the World Performance Project at Yale Records
World Performance Project at Yale records
titlestmt.author: by Susan Brady

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 11, 2019 at 03:01

did.unittitle: World Performance Project at Yale records

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The World Performance Project at Yale Records include performance programs, posters, and other publicity materials; participant contracts and agreements; administrative files; and audiovisual material and digital files that document the Project's performances, workshops, discussions, symposia and other events and activities from 2006 through 2012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Box 7 (audiovisual material) : Restricted fragile material. Digital surrogates may be viewed in the reading room. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 8-9 (digital media) : Restricted fragile material. Digital surrogates may be viewed in the reading room. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Publicity, 2006-2012. II. Contracts and Agreements, 2006-2012. III. Administrative Files, 2006-2012. IV. Audiovisual Material. V. Digital Media, 2006-2012.

bioghist.head: World Performance Project at Yale, 2006-2012
bioghist.p: In 2006, Joseph Roach, Charles C. and Dorathea S. Dilley Professor of Theater and English at Yale University, received a Distinguished Achievement Award from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. The award recognizes scholars who have made significant contributions to the humanities and enlarged opportunities for scholarship at their institutions, and intends to provide recipients and their institutions with resources to deepen their scholarship. Through funding provided with the award, Professor Roach established the World Performance Project at Yale (WPP). The three-year project was extended through 2012, with funding from the University and residual funds from the initial grant. Affiliated with the Yale College Theater Studies Program and the Whitney Humanities Center, the Project brought artists from throughout the United States, Europe, Latin America, Africa, and Asia to perform and engage in conversations with members of the Yale and the greater New Haven communities. In 2007, the Yale Repertory Theatre joined the World Performance Project in presenting international work and artists in the first of the "No Boundaries" season series, and continued the series after the WPP ended in 2012.

As described in its first season brochure, "The World Performance Project (WPP) promotes programs in performance studies across departments at Yale. An interdiscipline that draws from the arts, humanities, and human sciences (theater, drama, dance, visual arts, speech, linguistics, anthropology, sociology), performances studies defines as its objects cultural performances of all kinds, from theatrical presentations to rites of passage, and it expands it frontiers anywhere significant performances are likely to take place, from Yorubaland to Disneyland. … With performance-as-research in mind, the WPP presents performances, workshops, master classes, lectures, and residencies by artists and scholars working in dance, theater, music, performance art, and cultural performance. The WPP strives to frame each event in pre- and post-performance discussion in an effort to deepen the critical reception of the work. Serving as a central presenting organization, the WPP initiates performance-related events, as it assists and collaborates with departments and programs through the university seeking to enhance their curriculum through live performance."

Professor Roach served as principal investigator of the Project; Emily Coates, a lecturer in the Yale College Theater Studies program and a professional dancer, served as artistic director; and Kathryn Krier, who was design advisor for the Theater Studies Program, served as technical director/production manager.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The World Performance Project at Yale Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.
Box 7 (audiovisual material) : For research use only. May not be duplicated. Permission to copy must be obtained from the copyright holder. Consult the appropriate curator for further information.
Boxes 8-9 (digital media) : For research use only. May not be duplicated. Permission to copy must be obtained from the copyright holder. Consult the appropriate curator for further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: World Performance Project at Yale Records. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards. For more information, please refer to the Beinecke Manuscript Unit Processing Manual.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The World Performance Project at Yale Records include performance programs, posters, and other publicity materials; participant contracts and agreements; administrative files; and audiovisual material and digital files that document the Project's performances, workshops, discussions, symposia and other events and activities from 2006 through 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by date of performance/event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Performance and event programs, posters, flyers and tickets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recordings of performances, talks, and interviews, as well as photographs and files and screen shots of WPP website on CDs, DVDs, and USB drives.

did.unittitle: Recordings of performances, talks, and interviews on 97 DVDs
Recordings of performances, talks, and interviews on 13 CDs and 42 DVDs
Screen shots of WPP website on one CD
Photographs and files on two thumb drives
